*[a discussion](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1BnmeU5aYp435knSC:-Kp1BnmeU5aYp435knSD:b-9uyfeq) (no related file):*
This departs from the current approach to metrics. Rather than allowing a runner to choose how to report metrics, it pushes drop wizard into the cross-runner implementation. This has other affects too, such as making it impossible to support meters across only the successfully committed work.

A lot of the complexity seems to come from the trying to use drop wizard directly while also supporting the general case of metrics with committed values if a runner supports them.

I'd like to see a discussion on the dev@ list about whether moving towards the workers reporting metrics directly to a plugin. If we like this approach, it means we can remove all the cruft around combining/storing metrics in separate cells/etc. Assuming that makes sense, we should still think about whether we want that top level connection to be made directly to drop wizard or through a layer of indirection allowing other libraries.

---

*[pom.xml, line 1140 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp19tbbylCvL-_NJvd_:-Kp19tbbylCvL-_NJvda:b-whggvx) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/aa9bff62c8b88cc8c6a36ec224b799d7217dbb4d/pom.xml#L1140)):*

> 
>       <dependency>
>         <groupId>io.dropwizard.metrics</groupId>
> ```

Why are we adding dropwizard as a top-level dependency?

*[runners/core-java/pom.xml, line 99 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1AA0Vvad8uhYwzMca:-Kp1AA0Vvad8uhYwzMcb:bl4kp1j) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/aa9bff62c8b88cc8c6a36ec224b799d7217dbb4d/runners/core-java/pom.xml#L99)):*

> ```

---

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterCell.java, line 38 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1AGjycjkaup_Fr4lL:-Kp1AGjycjkaup_Fr4lM:bbv5jnb) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/aa9bff62c8b88cc8c6a36ec224b799d7217dbb4d/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterCell.java#L38)):*
> ```Java
> 
>   private final DirtyState dirty = new DirtyState();
>   private transient com.codahale.metrics.Meter value = new com.codahale.metrics.Meter();
> ```

Wrapping Meter like this will make it impossible for any runner to implement meters without using a drop wizard Meter. I believe that also makes it impossible to support committed values. This part of the implementation should instead capture enough information about the reported rate to export information to drop wizard within specific runners.

---

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterCell.java, line 73 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1AXj1Ga34Inr-wHGE:-Kp1AXj1Ga34Inr-wHGF:b-y750qf) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/aa9bff62c8b88cc8c6a36ec224b799d7217dbb4d/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterCell.java#L73)):*
> ```Java
>         value.getFiveMinuteRate(),
>         value.getFifteenMinuteRate(),
>         value.getMeanRate());
> ```

How would this data be mergeable? If the times aren't properly aligned, we can't just add the rates together, correct?

---

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterData.java, line 49 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1Adm0vIK3FzCRiXe0:-Kp1Adm0vIK3FzCRiXe1:bskx4h) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/aa9bff62c8b88cc8c6a36ec224b799d7217dbb4d/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterData.java#L49)):*
> ```Java
>         m5() + other.m5(),
>         m15() + other.m15(),
>         mean() + other.mean());
> ```

Adding mean rates together isn't sufficient for combining.

Consider:

A MeterData from 7:00 to 10:00 (3 hours) with an average rate of 100 and
A MeterData from 9:00 to 10:00 (1 hour) with an average rate of 100.

Why is the output rate an average of 200? If we assume the rate was evenly distributed, then we have:

2 hours with a rate of 33/hour, and 1 hour with a rate of 133/hour, etc.

Previously, bjchambers (Ben Chambers) wrote…
Adding mean rates together isn't sufficient for combining. Consider: A MeterData from 7:00 to 10:00 (3 hours) with an average rate of 100 and A MeterData from 9:00 to 10:00 (1 hour) with an average rate of 100. Why is the output rate an average of 200? If we assume the rate was evenly distributed, then we have: 2 hours with a rate of 33/hour, and 1 hour with a rate of 133/hour, etc.
Another similar problem -- we may get two meter data from the same thread that include overlapping rates. Again, adding the average rates together may cause numerical problems such as double counting (the overlap) or being drawn from different ranges (the example described above). --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555)*

Previously, bjchambers (Ben Chambers) wrote…
This departs from the current approach to metrics. Rather than allowing a runner to choose how to report metrics, it pushes drop wizard into the cross-runner implementation. This has other affects too, such as making it impossible to support meters across only the successfully committed work. A lot of the complexity seems to come from the trying to use drop wizard directly while also supporting the general case of metrics with committed values if a runner supports them. I'd like to see a discussion on the dev@ list about whether moving towards the workers reporting metrics directly to a plugin. If we like this approach, it means we can remove all the cruft around combining/storing metrics in separate cells/etc. Assuming that makes sense, we should still think about whether we want that top level connection to be made directly to drop wizard or through a layer of indirection allowing other libraries.
Ben, Thanks for your comments. I'm ok to extend the discussion further before pulling this commit. So I'll reply on my proposal doc. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555)*

*[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterCell.java, line 73 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1AXj1Ga34Inr-wHGE:-Kp3j5qqlTDPpPMWA1BI:b-3jlml2) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/aa9bff62c8b88cc8c6a36ec224b799d7217dbb4d/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterCell.java#L73)):*
> support
There're two ways currently to merge metrics. The first is through Accumulators, in Flink, this works only after the job has finished (doesn't make too much sense for streaming apps IMHO), and since it's one-time-off merging, perhaps alignment doesn't matter.
The other way is forwarding beam metrics to runner metrics(current implementation) or delegating beam metrics to runner metrics(my proposal). For the former, currently we only use the count of Meter to update runner's Meter and drop m1, m5, m15 and mean rates(they're only used for Accumulators). For the latter, it's simpler because "Meter.mark" in beam calls directly to runner's "Meter.mark" and we don't even bother about merging, it's the job of external services like OpenTSDB. And it depends on metrics reporters to align the metrics.

---


*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555)*

Previously, bjchambers (Ben Chambers) wrote…
Wrapping Meter like this will make it impossible for any runner to implement meters without using a drop wizard Meter. I believe that also makes it impossible to support committed values. This part of the implementation should instead capture enough information about the reported rate to export information to drop wizard within specific runners.
It's ok for runners to implement meters without using a dropwizard Meter because my implementation only passes the Meter.count() to runners and based on the count, the runners are free to implement their own meters. --- *[runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterData.java, line 49 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555#-Kp1Adm0vIK3FzCRiXe0:-KpEkDqh7BYZHM1mK8Ur:b-u1tym8) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/aa9bff62c8b88cc8c6a36ec224b799d7217dbb4d/runners/core-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/metrics/MeterData.java#L49)):*
Previously, bjchambers (Ben Chambers) wrote…
Another similar problem -- we may get two meter data from the same thread that include overlapping rates. Again, adding the average rates together may cause numerical problems such as double counting (the overlap) or being drawn from different ranges (the example described above).
This is a point we need to consider: In a distributed application, is the sum of `mean` rates referable? Or can we calculate an accurate sum of mean rates? Especially for meters with different start times. I think m1,m5,m15 are more referable numbers. Even so, I still think your example is reasonable acceptable because the mean rate of each meter depicts the average rate calculated so far, i.e, an static value at 10:00, it makes sense to sum them together to get a total mean rate for all meters at that time. For the second problem, I'm not sure about the use case, could you take an example? --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/3555)*
